**Has a **terrible habit of **eavesdropping**—he **knows everything** that happens in the manor. - **Collects **old **newspapers**—he **reads them **cover to cover**, **even the **obituaries**. - **Hates **lavender** (it **smells like **his ex-wife**, who **left him**). - **Has a **soft spot for **street cats**—he **feeds them**, but **denies it**. **Flaws:** - **Cynical**—he **doesn’t believe in **happily ever after**. - **Secretive**—he **won’t tell anyone his **real past**. - **Stubborn**—he **won’t ask for help**, even when he **needs it**. - **Guilty**—he **blames himself for the **case that went wrong**. - **Loyal to a fault**—he **won’t betray the Blackwoods**, even if they **don’t deserve it**. **Physicality:** - **Height:** 6’0” (he **hates how tall he is**—**feels like he’s **always looming**). - **Build:** **Lean, **wiry**—**not a **fighter**, but **not weak**. - **Hands:** **Rough, **calloused** (from **years of **polishing silver and **breaking up fights**). - **Hair:** **Gray, **always **neat**, **a **habit of **running a hand through it** when he’s **nervous**. - **Eyes:** **Brown, **sharp**—people say he **looks at them like he’s **measuring them for a coffin**. - **Clothing:** **Wears **black suits**, **always **impeccably tailored**, **a **habit of **adjusting his cuffs** when he’s **nervous**. - **Posture:** **Stands **too straight**, **moves like a **soldier** (he **was in the military before Bow Street**). - **Voice:** **Low, **gruff**—sounds like **gravel and whiskey**. **Motives & Allegiances:** - **Primary Motive:** **Redemption.** He **wants to **make up for the **case that went wrong**. - **Secondary Motive:** **Protecting Alistair.** He **sees himself in him**—a **man who’s **given up on fighting**. - **Allegiances:** - **Alistair Blackwood**—he **sees himself in him**. - **Nora Whitmore**—he **respects her**—she’s **the first person who’s ever **treated him like an equal**. - **Lady Beatrice**—he **knows her secrets**, but he **won’t betray her**. **Relationships:** - **Alistair Blackwood:** **The **son he never had**. He **protects him**, **teases him**, **tells him the **hard truths**. - **Dynamic:** **Graves is **like a **gruff uncle**, Alistair is **the **reluctant nephew**. - **Quote (Graves):** *"You’re **not as **broken as you think, boy**. But you’re **broken enough**."* - **Nora Whitmore:** **The **only person who’s ever **treated him like an equal**. He **respects her**, but he **doesn’t trust her** (yet). - **Dynamic:** **She **teases him**, he **acts like he **hates it**. - **Quote (Nora):** *"You’re **not as **scary as you think, old man**."* - **Lady Beatrice:** **His **employer, his **secret-keeper**. He **knows her crimes**, but he **won’t expose her**. - **Dynamic:** **She **trusts him**, he **doesn’t judge her**. - **Quote (Graves, internal):** *"She’s **not a **good woman**. But she’s **not a **monster** either."* **Flavor Dialogue / Internal Monologue:** - **Graves, **dry**, after Nora **complains about the **manor’s **ghost**: - *"Ghosts **don’t exist**, Miss Whitmore. **Only **liars and **cowards**."* - **Graves, **whispering to himself**, after he **sees Lady Beatrice **poison her tea**: - *"I **should’ve stopped her**. But I **didn’t**. And now it’s **too late**."* - **Graves, **talking to a **street cat** he’s **feeding**: - *"You’re **judging me**. I **see** it in your **eyes**."* - **Graves, **yelling at Alistair** after he **almost gets himself killed**: - *"You’re **an idiot**, boy. And I’m **too old to **watch you **die**."* - **Graves, **internal monologue**, after he **realizes he’s **starting to care about Nora**: - *"She’s **trouble**. And I **don’t do **trouble**. But **damn it**, I **like her**."* --- # **Character 5: Lady Beatrice Blackwood** ### **Background** **Full Name:** Beatrice Blackwood **Age:** 50 **Class:** **Noblewoman, widow, **matriarch of the Blackwood family**. **Background:** - **Married young** to a **wealthy but **cruel man** (Lord Blackwood, Sr.), who **died under mysterious circumstances**. - **Took over the **Blackwood estate** after her brother-in-law’s death. - **Hosts **house parties** to **marry off Alistair** and **restore the family’s reputation**. - **But she’s **hiding something**—she **knows who killed Lady Eleanor**, and she’s **involved in the smuggling ring**. **Personality & Idyncrasies:** - **Elegant, **poised**, **always **in control**. - **Hates **messy emotions**—she **prefers **polite lies** to **honest truths**. - **Has a **terrible habit of **playing with her **jewelry** when she’s **nervous** (twirling a **ring around her finger**). - **Collects **rare perfumes**—she **has a **different scent for every mood**. - **Hates **lavender** (it **smells like **her late husband**). - **Has a **soft spot for **stray dogs**—she **feeds them**, but **denies it**. **Flaws:** - **Manipulative**—she **plays people like **chess pieces**. - **Selfish**—she **loves her family**, but she **loves her **reputation more**. - **Guilty**—she **knows she **caused her sister-in-law’s death**, and she **can’t forgive herself**. - **Prideful**—she **won’t admit she’s wrong**, even when she **is**. - **Lonely**—she **pushes people away**, but she **hates being alone**. **Physicality:** - **Height:** 5’8” (she **hates being tall**—**feels like she’s **always looming**). - **Build:** **Slender, **elegant**—**moves like a **cat burglar** (because she **was one, once**). - **Hands:** **Always **manicured**, **a **habit of **twirling a **ring around her finger** when she’s **nervous**. - **Hair:** **Silver-blonde, **always **perfectly styled**, **a **habit of **touching her **necklace** when she’s **lying**. - **Eyes:** **Blue, **cold**—people say she **looks at them like she’s **measuring them for a coffin**. - **Clothing:** **Wears **dark colors**, **always **impeccably tailored**, **a **habit of **adjusting her **gloves** when she’s **nervous**. - **Posture:** **Stands **too straight**, **moves like a **queen** (because she **was one, in her own mind**). - **Voice:** **Low, **smooth**—sounds like **honey and poison**. **Motives & Allegiances:** - **Primary Motive:** **Protecting the Blackwood name**—even if it **means lying, cheating, or killing**. - **Secondary Motive:** **Protecting Alistair**—she **loves him**, but she **doesn’t know how to **show it**. - **Allegiances:** - **Alistair Blackwood**—her **nephew, her **last family**. - **Mr. Graves**—he **knows her secrets**, but he **won’t betray her**. - **Sir Reginald Holloway**—her **partner in crime** (but she **doesn’t trust him**). **Relationships:** - **Alistair Blackwood:** **Her **nephew, her **last family**. She **loves him**, but she **doesn’t know how to **show it**. - **Dynamic:** **She **wants to **marry him off**, he **wants to **disappear**. - **Quote (Beatrice):** *"You’re **wasting your life**, Alistair. And I **won’t let you**."* - **Mr. Graves:** **The **only person who knows her **secrets**. She **trusts him**, but she **doesn’t like it**. - **Dynamic:** **He **knows too much**, she **pretends he doesn’t**. - **Quote (Graves):** *"You’re **not as **good as you think, my lady**. But you’re **not as **bad** either."* - **Sir Reginald Holloway:** **Her **partner in crime**. She **doesn’t trust him**, but she **needs him**. - **Dynamic:** **She **plays him**, he **plays her**. - **Quote (Beatrice, internal):** *"He’s **useful**. But **useful things** have a **habit of **breaking**."* **Flavor Dialogue / Internal Monologue:** - **Beatrice, **smooth**, after Alistair **refuses to **marry the woman she’s chosen for him:** - *"You’re **being **childish**, Alistair. And I **don’t have time for **children**."* - **Beatrice, **whispering to herself**, after she **poisons her tea:** - *"It’s **just a **little **arsenic**. No one will **notice**."* - **Beatrice, **talking to her **stray dog**, **Brutus**: - *"You’re **judging me**. I **see** it in your **eyes**."* - **Beatrice, **yelling at Graves** after he **catches her **lying**: - *"You’re **impertinent**, Graves. And I **don’t pay you to **think**."* - **Beatrice, **internal monologue**, after she **realizes she’s **starting to care about Nora**: - *"She’s **trouble**. And I **don’t do **trouble**. But **damn it**, I **like her**."* --- # **Final Notes on Character Arcs** - **Nora:** **Learns to trust**—but **not easily**. - **Alistair:** **Learns to fight**—but **not without cost**. - **Lottie:** **Learns to be **loyal without being **reckless**. - **Graves:** **Learns to **forgive himself**—but **not without guilt**. - **Beatrice:** **Learns that **some secrets are better left buried**—but **not without consequence**. **Next Steps:** - **Finalize the **chapter-by-chapter dialogue** with these **voices in mind**. - **Decide on **key scenes** where these **personalities will **shine** (e.g., **Nora’s lockpicking failure**, **Alistair’s silence**, **Lottie’s recklessness**, **Graves’ guilt**, **Beatrice’s manipulation**). - **Draft **Chapter 1** with **these characters fully realized**.

+ Romance — Love in the Limelight (Chapter Avg: 57.8 | Final: 35.4)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write a short story set in Wales. Task: write a short story over several chapters. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The story takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the first scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. The story will progress beyond this synopsis, and it's up to you where it goes.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write a short story set in Wales. Task: write a short story over several chapters. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The story takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the first scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor&#x27;s charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. The story will progress beyond this synopsis, and it&#x27;s up to you where it goes. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
--- ### **# Brainstorming** #### **Characters** **1. The Actor (Liam Calloway)** - **Personality Traits:** - A rogue with a fragile ego—charming, witty, and effortlessly charismatic, but secretly desperate for validation. - Used to being the center of attention, but the paparazzi chase has left him unnerved, making him more vulnerable than usual. - His charm is a shield; when it doesn’t work (as with the bookstore owner), it throws him off balance. - Has a self-deprecating humor that disarms people, but it’s also a way to fish for compliments. - Physically: Lean, sharp features, dark hair, always dressed like he’s stepped out of a magazine (even in a crisis). - **Backstory Hooks:** - Recently wrapped a high-profile film that’s caused a media frenzy—maybe a scandal (fake relationship, on-set feud, or a role that’s too personal). - Hails from a working-class background in Wales (or England) but reinvented himself in Hollywood, so he’s both proud and ashamed of his roots. - Has a reputation as a heartbreaker, but in reality, he’s never let anyone get close enough to *actually* break his heart. - **Voice & Dialogue:** - Smooth, slightly teasing, with a hint of a Welsh accent (or a posh English one if he’s trying to hide his roots). - Uses humor to deflect, but when he’s genuinely interested, his words become more deliberate, less performative. - Example lines: - *"You’re the first person in months who hasn’t either fawned over me or tried to sell me out. I’m not sure if I’m relieved or insulted."* - *"I usually have a better opening line than ‘please don’t call the paparazzi,’ but here we are."* **2. The Bookstore Owner (Elen Morgan)** - **Personality Traits:** - Dry, sharp-witted, and unimpressed by fame—*or so she seems*. - Runs a struggling independent bookstore in a small Welsh town (think: cobblestone streets, rain-slicked windows, the scent of old paper and tea). - Secretly a romantic (she loves gothic novels and old poetry) but would *never* admit it. - Has a no-nonsense exterior but is actually deeply empathetic—she notices the way Liam’s hands shake when he thinks she’s not looking. - **Backstory Hooks:** - Grew up in the town, never left. Her parents owned the bookstore before her; it’s her whole life. - Has a quiet, simmering resentment toward "outsiders" (like Liam) who waltz in and out of small towns, leaving chaos behind. - Might have had a past heartbreak—maybe a local boy who left for the city, or a failed relationship that made her cynical. - **Secret Soft Spot:** She’s a huge fan of Liam’s *work* (but would die before admitting it). - **Voice & Dialogue:** - Blunt, no-nonsense, with a musical Welsh lilt. - Uses sarcasm as a defense mechanism, but her tone softens when she’s caught off guard. - Example lines: - *"Aye, well, if you’re hiding from the press, you’ve picked the wrong place. This town’s got nothing but gossip and sheep."* - *"You’re not as charming as you think you are. But you’re *trying* harder than most, I’ll give you that."* - (Later, when she’s flustered:) *"I—just—stop looking at me like that. It’s unnerving."* **3. Supporting Characters (Potential for Later Chapters)** - **Dafydd (Elen’s Best Friend & the Local Pub Owner):** - A burly, warm-hearted man who’s known Elen since childhood. He’s the first to notice her weird behavior after Liam’s arrival. - Acts as the voice of reason (or the instigator, depending on the scene). - **Dialogue Style:** Gruff but kind, with a dry sense of humor. - *"So. You’ve got a *film star* hiding in your back room. Care to explain, or should I start taking bets on how long till the tabloids find him?"* - **Seren (Elen’s Younger Sister, a Teenager):** - A Liam Calloway *stan*—knows every role, every rumor, every interview. - Throws Elen under the bus immediately when she realizes who’s in the shop. - **Dialogue Style:** Excited, dramatic, relentless. - *"OH MY GOD, YOU’RE LYING. HE’S *HERE*? IN *OUR* BOOKSHOP? Elen, if you don’t let me meet him, I will *die*."* - **The Paparazzi (Antagonistic Force):** - A sleazy photographer (maybe named *Gary*) who’s been tailing Liam for weeks, determined to get *the* shot. - Shows up in Chapter 3, causing chaos in the town. - **Dialogue Style:** Smarmy, invasive, always angling for a reaction. - *"Come on, Liam, just one smile for the camera. Or are you too busy slumming it in the middle of nowhere?"* --- #### **Setting** - **The Bookstore (Ty Llyfr Elen):** - A narrow, two-story shop in a Welsh market town (think: **Hay-on-Wye** but smaller, quieter). - Creaky wooden floors, shelves packed with books (some dusty, some new), a tiny café nook with a kettle and mismatched mugs. - The back room is cluttered with boxes, an old armchair, and a window that overlooks the alley—where Liam first ducks in. - **Atmosphere:** Cozy but slightly decaying (like a beloved sweater with holes). Rain taps against the windows. The scent of old paper and Earl Grey tea lingers. - **The Town (Llanfair or something equally Welsh):** - A place where everyone knows everyone. The local pub (*The Dragon’s Head*) is the hub of gossip. - The landscape is lush and green—rolling hills, a river, sheep dotting the fields. - The town is *pissed* about the paparazzi invading their peace. --- #### **Plot Beats (Possible Directions)** **Chapter 1: The Hideout (Meet-Cute/Gone Wrong)** - Liam bursts into the bookstore, breathless, asking Elen to hide him. - She’s skeptical, but something about his panic makes her relent (maybe she recognizes him but won’t admit it). - Their first conversation is a battle of wits—he tries to charm her; she shuts it down. - **Key Moment:** He notices a book she’s reading (*Wuthering Heights*) and teases her about it. She snaps back, but he *sees* her—really sees her—for the first time. - **Ending:** The paparazzi pass by the window. Liam tenses. Elen, without thinking, pulls him into the back room. Their hands brush. A beat of silence. **Chapter 2: The Truce (Forced Proximity)** - Liam is stuck in the bookstore for the night (the paparazzi are camped outside). - Elen is *furious* at the disruption but also… intrigued. - They bicker over tea and biscuits. He tries to impress her with Hollywood stories; she calls him out on his bullshit. - **Key Moment:** He admits he’s terrified of being exposed as a fraud. She softens—just a little. - **Ending:** She lends him a book (*The Great Gatsby*). He reads a passage aloud to her. She pretends not to be affected. **Chapter 3: The Town Finds Out (Chaos Ensues)** - Seren walks in and *loses her mind* when she sees Liam. - The secret is out. The town is abuzz. The paparazzi swarm. - Elen is mortified. Liam is… oddly protective of her. - **Key Moment:** A photographer shoves a camera in Elen’s face. Liam steps between them, snarling. She’s shocked—no one’s ever defended her like that. - **Ending:** The local constable (a gruff but fair man) kicks the paparazzi out of town—for now. Liam is "invited" to stay at the pub (Dafydd’s place) to lay low. **Chapter 4: The Pub (Public Scrutiny)** - Liam is now *everyone’s* problem. The town is divided—some love him, some resent the disruption. - Elen avoids him, but he seeks her out. They argue in the pub’s garden. - **Key Moment:** He asks why she’s so determined to hate him. She snaps: *"Because people like you don’t stay. And I’m not some holiday fling for a celebrity."* - **Ending:** A storm rolls in. They’re forced to take shelter in the pub’s cellar. Tension simmers. **Chapter 5: The Confession (Vulnerability)** - Trapped in the cellar, they talk—really talk. - Liam admits he’s lonely. Elen admits she’s afraid of being left behind. - **Key Moment:** He kisses her. She kisses back—then pushes him away. *"This is a bad idea."* - **Ending:** The storm passes. They emerge to find the town has *thrown a party* in Liam’s honor. He’s horrified. She’s amused. **Chapter 6: The Scandal (External Conflict)** - A tabloid runs a story: *"LIAM CALLOWAY’S SECRET WELSH LOVER!"* (Complete with a blurry photo of them in the bookstore.) - Elen is humiliated. Liam is *furious*—not at the exposure, but at the invasion of *her* privacy. - **Key Moment:** He offers to leave town to protect her. She refuses. *"I’m not hiding. And neither are you."* - **Ending:** They devise a plan—to give the paparazzi *exactly* what they want… but on their terms. **Chapter 7: The Performance (Fake Dating?)** - They stage a "romantic" walk through town, feeding the paparazzi a story. - But the lines blur. The kisses feel real. The town starts shipping them. - **Key Moment:** Liam’s manager calls, offering him a *huge* role—if he dumps Elen for a "more marketable" girlfriend. - **Ending:** Liam hesitates. Elen overhears. She’s gutted. **Chapter 8: The Choice (Resolution)** - Liam shows up at the bookstore, ready to grovel. Elen is ice-cold. - He admits he turned down the role. *"I’d rather be here. With you."* - **Key Moment:** She calls his bluff—*"Prove it. Stay. Not for a week. Not for a scandal. Stay."* - **Ending:** He does. The paparazzi leave. The town accepts him. And in the quiet of the bookstore, with rain on the windows, he reads to her from *North and South*—and this time, she doesn’t pretend not to listen. --- #### **Tone & Themes** - **Tone:** - **Chapter 1-3:** Witty, tense, with a slow-burn romantic undercurrent. Think *Pride and Prejudice* meets *Notting Hill*. - **Chapter 4-6:** More emotional, with moments of vulnerability. The humor is still there, but it’s softer. - **Chapter 7-8:** High stakes, but with a hopeful resolution. The ending should feel *earned*—not forced. - **Themes:** - **Authenticity vs. Performance:** Liam’s entire life is an act. Elen is the first person who sees through it—and makes him want to be real. - **Belonging:** Liam has never had a home. Elen has never left hers. Can they find a middle ground? - **Small Town vs. Big World:** The clash between Elen’s rooted life and Liam’s transient one. - **The Illusion of Fame:** How Liam’s charm is a shield, and how Elen’s indifference is the first thing that *actually* reaches him. --- #### **Pacing & Structure** | **Chapter** | **Word Count** | **Key Events** | **Emotional Arc** | |-------------|----------------|----------------|-------------------| | **1** | 1000 | Meet-cute/gone wrong. Forced proximity in the bookstore. | Tension, curiosity, first sparks of attraction. | | **2** | 1000 | Forced to interact overnight. Bickering turns to vulnerability. | Softening, reluctant admiration. | | **3** | 1000 | The secret is out. Town reacts. Liam is "invited" to stay. | Frustration, protectiveness, first real connection. | | **4** | 1000 | Public scrutiny. Argument in the pub garden. | Raw emotions, fear of abandonment. | | **5** | 1000 | Storm forces intimacy. Confessions. First kiss. | Vulnerability, hope, then doubt. | | **6** | 1000 | Tabloid scandal. Liam’s manager calls. | Betrayal, anger, ultimatum. | | **7** | 1000 | Fake dating gone wrong. Lines blur. | Confusion, heartbreak, realization. | | **8** | 1000 | Liam chooses Elen. Happy(ish) ending. | Resolution, commitment, quiet joy. | --- --- ### **# Reflection** #### **What Works?** 1. **The Premise is Strong:** - The "famous actor hiding in a small-town bookstore" setup is *classic rom-com gold*, but the Welsh setting adds a fresh, cozy, *specific* flavor. - The dynamic between Liam (charming but fragile) and Elen (unimpressed but secretly soft) has *great* potential for push-pull tension. 2. **The Characters Have Clear Arcs:** - **Liam:** Starts as a performative rogue, ends as someone willing to be vulnerable. His growth is about *earning* love instead of demanding it. - **Elen:** Starts as cynical and closed-off, ends as someone who learns to trust—and to ask for what she wants. - Their flaws *complement* each other: his need for validation clashes with her self-sufficiency, but that’s what makes them *need* each other. 3. **The Setting is Rich with Possibilities:** - A small Welsh town is *perfect* for this—it’s intimate, gossip-filled, and visually stunning (rain, hills, bookshops, pubs). - The contrast between Liam’s glamorous world and Elen’s rooted life creates *natural* conflict and chemistry. 4. **The Dialogue Has Potential for Sharp, Witty Banter:** - Their first conversation could be *hilarious* if played right—him trying to charm her, her shutting him down with dry Welsh sarcasm. - The humor could evolve into something deeper as they lower their guards. 5. **The Stakes Feel Personal:** - It’s not just about "will they/won’t they?"—it’s about *what they’re willing to give up* to be together. - Liam has to choose between fame and love. Elen has to risk her heart (and her town’s judgment) on an outsider. #### **What Doesn’t Work (or Needs Refinement)?** 1. **The Paparazzi Might Feel Like a Cartoonish Villain:** - Right now, they’re a convenient plot device, but they could *easily* become a one-note annoyance. - **Fix:** Give them a human face—maybe one is a local who’s desperate for money, or one is a former friend of Liam’s. Make their invasion *personal*. 2. **Elen’s Immunity to Liam’s Charm Might Feel Unrealistic (or Uninteresting):** - If she’s *completely* immune, it risks feeling like she’s just a plot device to "tame" him. - **Fix:** She *is* charmed—she just *hates* that she is. Show her internal conflict. Maybe she catches herself laughing at his jokes and *immediately* shuts it down. 3. **The Fake Dating Trope Could Feel Overdone:** - It’s a classic, but it risks making the story predictable. - **Fix:** Twist it—maybe they *don’t* fake date. Maybe they *refuse* to play into the scandal, which forces Liam to confront his fear of public rejection. 4. **The Ending Might Feel Too Neat:** - Liam "chooses love" and stays in the town—cute, but does it *really* fit his character? - **Fix:** Maybe he *doesn’t* stay—maybe he goes back to L.A., but *this time*, he invites Elen to visit. Or maybe they compromise: he keeps a home in Wales but splits time between there and Hollywood. *Something* that shows growth without being *too* easy. 5. **The Welsh Setting Could Be Underutilized:** - Right now, it’s mostly a *backdrop*. But it could be *central* to the story—maybe the town’s history, language, or culture plays a role in their conflict. - **Fix:** Weave in Welsh phrases, local traditions (like a *eisteddfod* or a *gorsaf* festival), or even have Elen teach Liam a few words—leading to a sweet or funny moment. 6. **The Supporting Characters Might Feel Like Extras:** - Dafydd and Seren could be *so* much fun, but right now, they’re just "the best friend" and "the sister." - **Fix:** Give them *agendas*. Maybe Dafydd *hates* celebrities and is suspicious of Liam. Maybe Seren *ships* them so hard she accidentally leaks their location to the press. #### **Biggest Strengths to Lean Into:** - **The Chemistry:** The push-pull between Liam’s charm and Elen’s resistance is *gold*. Play up the moments where she *almost* gives in, then catches herself. - **The Setting as a Character:** Make the town *matter*. The bookstore isn’t just a hideout—it’s Elen’s *life*. The pub isn’t just a place to drink—it’s where the town gossips. The landscape (rain, hills, the river) should *feel* like a character in its own right. - **The Emotional Core:** This isn’t just a rom-com—it’s about *fear of abandonment* (Liam) and *fear of being left behind* (Elen). Lean into those vulnerabilities. #### **Potential Pitfalls to Avoid:** - **Making Liam Too Much of a Jerk:** He’s a rogue, but he can’t be *unlikable*. His charm should feel *earned*, not forced. - **Making Elen Too Cynical:** She’s guarded, but she can’t be *unreachable*. Show her soft moments—maybe she has a secret stash of romance novels, or she’s secretly a softie for stray cats. - **Rushing the Romance:** Let the tension *simmer*. The first half should be *mostly* bickering and slow burns, with the payoff coming in the second half. - **Ignoring the Welsh Culture:** Don’t just *mention* Wales—*use* it. The language, the landscape, the community should feel *integral* to the story. #### **Final Thoughts:** This has *huge* potential to be a **witty, heartfelt, visually rich** romance with a fresh setting and a dynamic duo who *really* bring out the best (and worst) in each other. The key will be: 1. **Balancing the humor and the heart**—keeping the banter sharp but ensuring the emotional beats *land*. 2. **Making the setting *matter***—not just as a backdrop, but as a *character* in its own right. 3. **Giving both characters *clear, compelling arcs***—Liam’s journey from performative charm to genuine vulnerability, and Elen’s journey from guarded cynicism to opening her heart. If I were to start writing this *today*, I’d focus on: - **Chapter 1’s dialogue**—nailing that first meeting, where Liam’s charm *fails* and Elen’s indifference *intrigues* him. - **The bookstore’s atmosphere**—making it feel like a *living, breathing* place, not just a set. - **The undercurrent of chemistry**—even when they’re bickering, there should be *something* simmering beneath the surface. --- **Next Steps:** - Outline **Chapter 1** in *full* (dialogue, beats, emotional shifts). - Decide on **key Welsh details** to weave in (language, culture, landscape). - Brainstorm **specific scenes** for the paparazzi’s invasion (how does the town react?). - Sketch out **Liam and Elen’s backstories** in more depth (what *specifically* makes them who they are?). Would you like me to draft **Chapter 1** next, or would you prefer to refine any part of the plan further?
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
--- ### **# Intention** #### **Core Intentions for the Story** This short story will be a **witty, emotionally rich romance** set in a **small Welsh town**, centered on the **clash and eventual connection** between a **charming but fragile Hollywood actor** and a **sharp-witted, guarded bookstore owner**. The tone will balance **humor, tension, and heartfelt vulnerability**, with a **strong emphasis on dialogue, setting, and character arcs**. --- #### **Key Choices & Intentions** **1. Plot & Structure** - **Avoid:** A predictable, formulaic rom-com. Instead, **lean into the push-pull dynamic** between Liam and Elen, ensuring their chemistry feels **earned and organic**. - **Embrace:** - **Forced proximity** (Liam hiding in the bookstore) as the **catalyst for their connection**. - **External conflict** (paparazzi, tabloids, town gossip) to **raise the stakes** and force them to confront their fears. - **A slow-burn romance**—the first half should be **mostly tension and banter**, with the emotional payoff coming in the second half. **2. Character Arcs** - **Liam Calloway:** - **Starts as:** A **charming, performative rogue** who relies on his wit and fame to mask his insecurities. - **Ends as:** Someone who **learns to be vulnerable**, choosing **authenticity over validation**. - **Key Moment:** He **turns down a major role** to stay with Elen, proving his growth. - **Elen Morgan:** - **Starts as:** A **cynical, guarded bookstore owner** who resists Liam’s charm out of self-preservation. - **Ends as:** Someone who **learns to trust** and **asks for what she wants**—even if it’s risky. - **Key Moment:** She **calls Liam out** on his bullshit, forcing him to **confront his fears**. **3. Voice & Dialogue** - **Avoid:** Overly polished, generic rom-com dialogue. Instead, **lean into their distinct voices**: - **Liam:** Smooth, teasing, with a **hint of a Welsh accent** (or a posh English one if hiding his roots). Uses **humor to deflect**, but his words become **more deliberate** when he’s genuinely interested. - **Elen:** **Dry, sharp, and unimpressed**—but with a **musical Welsh lilt**. Her **sarcasm is a defense mechanism**, but her tone **softens** when she’s caught off guard. - **Intentions:** - **Banter-heavy first half**, with **emotional depth** emerging as they lower their guards. - **Subtext is key**—their words should **reveal more than they intend**. **4. Setting & Atmosphere** - **Avoid:** Making Wales just a **backdrop**. Instead, **weave it into the story**: - The **bookstore** is a **living, breathing character**—creaky floors, the scent of old paper, rain on the windows. - The **town** is **intimate and gossip-filled**, with **local traditions** (e.g., a *eisteddfod* or a *gorsaf* festival) adding depth. - The **landscape** (rolling hills, rivers, sheep) should **feel like a character**—maybe Liam takes Elen on a walk, or they get caught in a storm. - **Stylistic Choices:** - **Sensory details** (the sound of rain, the smell of tea, the texture of old books) to **immerse the reader**. - **Welsh phrases** sprinkled naturally (e.g., *"Diolch"* for "thank you," *"Cwtch"* for "hug") to **ground the story in its setting**. **5. Themes** - **Authenticity vs. Performance:** Liam’s **entire life is an act**, but Elen **sees through it**—and makes him want to be real. - **Belonging:** Liam has **never had a home**; Elen has **never left hers**. Can they **find a middle ground**? - **Small Town vs. Big World:** The **clash between Elen’s rooted life and Liam’s transient one**. - **The Illusion of Fame:** How Liam’s **charm is a shield**, and how Elen’s **indifference is the first thing that *actually* reaches him**. **6. Tone & Pacing** - **First Half (Chapters 1-4):** **Witty, tense, slow-burn romance**—focus on **banter, forced proximity, and simmering attraction**. - **Second Half (Chapters 5-8):** **More emotional, higher stakes**—focus on **vulnerability, conflict, and resolution**. - **Pacing:** **Steady but deliberate**—let the **tension build** before the payoff. --- ### **# Chapter Planning** #### **Chapter 1: The Hideout (Meet-Cute/Gone Wrong)** - **Word Count:** 1000 - **Key Events:** - Liam **bursts into the bookstore**, breathless, asking Elen to hide him from the paparazzi. - She’s **skeptical but relents**, leading him to the back room. - Their **first conversation is a battle of wits**—he tries to charm her; she shuts it down. - **Key Moment:** He notices a book she’s reading (*Wuthering Heights*) and teases her. She snaps back, but he *sees* her—for the first time. - **Ending:** The paparazzi pass by the window. Liam tenses. Elen, without thinking, pulls him into the back room. Their hands brush. A beat of silence. #### **Chapter 2: The Truce (Forced Proximity)** - **Word Count:** 1000 - **Key Events:** - Liam is **stuck in the bookstore for the night** (paparazzi are camped outside). - Elen is **furious at the disruption** but also… intrigued. - They **bicker over tea and biscuits**. He tries to impress her with Hollywood stories; she calls him out on his bullshit. - **Key Moment:** He admits he’s **terrified of being exposed as a fraud**. She softens—just a little. - **Ending:** She lends him a book (*The Great Gatsby*). He reads a passage aloud to her. She pretends not to be affected. #### **Chapter 3: The Town Finds Out (Chaos Ensues)** - **Word Count:** 1000 - **Key Events:** - **Seren walks in and loses her mind** when she sees Liam. The secret is out. - The **town is abuzz**. The paparazzi swarm. - Elen is **mortified**. Liam is… oddly protective of her. - **Key Moment:** A photographer shoves a camera in Elen’s face. Liam steps between them, snarling. She’s shocked—no one’s ever defended her like that. - **Ending:** The local constable kicks the paparazzi out of town—for now. Liam is "invited" to stay at the pub (Dafydd’s place) to lay low. #### **Chapter 4: The Pub (Public Scrutiny)** - **Word Count:** 1000 - **Key Events:** - Liam is now **everyone’s problem**. The town is divided—some love him, some resent the disruption. - Elen **avoids him**, but he seeks her out. They argue in the pub’s garden. - **Key Moment:** He asks why she’s so determined to hate him. She snaps: *"Because people like you don’t stay. And I’m not some holiday fling for a celebrity."* - **Ending:** A **storm rolls in**. They’re forced to take shelter in the pub’s cellar. Tension simmers. #### **Chapter 5: The Confession (Vulnerability)** - **Word Count:** 1000 - **Key Events:** - **Trapped in the cellar**, they talk—*really* talk. - Liam admits he’s **lonely**. Elen admits she’s **afraid of being left behind**. - **Key Moment:** He kisses her. She kisses back—then pushes him away. *"This is a bad idea."* - **Ending:** The storm passes. They emerge to find the town has **thrown a party** in Liam’s honor. He’s horrified. She’s amused. #### **Chapter 6: The Scandal (External Conflict)** - **Word Count:** 1000 - **Key Events:** - A **tabloid runs a story**: *"LIAM CALLOWAY’S SECRET WELSH LOVER!"* (Complete with a blurry photo of them in the bookstore.) - Elen is **humiliated**. Liam is *furious*—not at the exposure, but at the invasion of *her* privacy. - **Key Moment:** He offers to leave town to protect her. She refuses. *"I’m not hiding. And neither are you."* - **Ending:** They devise a plan—to give the paparazzi *exactly* what they want… but on their terms. #### **Chapter 7: The Performance (Fake Dating?)** - **Word Count:** 1000 - **Key Events:** - They **stage a "romantic" walk through town**, feeding the paparazzi a story. - But the lines blur. The kisses feel real. The town starts shipping them. - **Key Moment:** Liam’s manager calls, offering him a **huge role**—if he dumps Elen for a "more marketable" girlfriend. - **Ending:** Liam hesitates. Elen overhears. She’s gutted. #### **Chapter 8: The Choice (Resolution)** - **Word Count:** 1000 - **Key Events:** - Liam shows up at the bookstore, ready to grovel. Elen is **ice-cold**. - He admits he **turned down the role**. *"I’d rather be here. With you."* - **Key Moment:** She calls his bluff—*"Prove it. Stay. Not for a week. Not for a scandal. Stay."* - **Ending:** He does. The paparazzi leave. The town accepts him. And in the quiet of the bookstore, with rain on the windows, he reads to her from *North and South*—and this time, she doesn’t pretend not to listen. --- **Next Steps:** - Draft **Chapter 1** in full, focusing on **dialogue, chemistry, and setting**. - Refine **Liam and Elen’s backstories** (what *specifically* makes them who they are?). - Decide on **key Welsh details** to weave in (language, culture, landscape).
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
--- ### **How a Human Might Approach This Piece (vs. LLM Tendencies)** #### **1. The Human Approach: Embracing Imperfection & Authenticity** A human writer approaching this story would likely: - **Write from personal experience or deep empathy**—even if they’ve never been a famous actor or a bookstore owner, they’d draw from their own relationships, insecurities, and observations of human behavior. - **Prioritize emotional truth over plot perfection**—they might let characters say or do things that don’t neatly serve the romance, because *that’s how people are*. - **Embrace awkwardness and realism**—real conversations aren’t always witty or perfectly structured. Humans might include moments of silence, miscommunication, or even boredom. - **Avoid "neat" resolutions**—a human might leave some threads unresolved, or end on a bittersweet note, because life doesn’t always wrap up in a bow. - **Write for themselves first**—they’d focus on the story that *they* find compelling, rather than what they think an audience "should" like. #### **2. Tell-Tale LLM Approaches (and Why They Might Not Serve This Piece)** LLMs (and AI-generated writing in general) often fall into patterns that can feel **too polished, too predictable, or too "safe."** Here’s how that might manifest in this story—and why it could undermine its humanity: | **LLM Tendency** | **How It Might Show Up in This Story** | **Why It’s Problematic** | **Human Alternative** | |----------------------------------|----------------------------------------|-------------------------|------------------------| | **Overly witty dialogue** | Every line is a zinger. Liam and Elen trade barbs like a rom-com script, with no lulls or awkwardness. | Feels forced, not organic. Real conversations have pauses, missteps, and moments of genuine connection. | Some lines land flat. There are silences. A joke falls apart because one of them is too nervous to laugh. | | **Neat, symmetrical character arcs** | Liam’s growth is a clean, three-act journey from "charming rogue" to "vulnerable lover." Elen’s arc mirrors his perfectly. | Feels like a formula. Real people don’t grow in such tidy ways—they backslide, they’re inconsistent. | Liam has a moment where he *almost* reverts to his old habits. Elen’s cynicism flares up at an unexpected moment. | | **Over-explaining emotions** | The narrative (or characters) constantly *tells* the reader how someone feels ("Liam’s heart raced with longing," "Elen’s walls crumbled"). | Feels heavy-handed. Readers should *infer* emotions from actions and subtext. | Show Liam fidgeting with his cufflinks when he’s nervous. Show Elen avoiding eye contact when she’s lying to herself. | | **Forced conflict for the sake of drama** | The paparazzi are an external threat that *only* exists to keep Liam and Elen apart. The town’s gossip is a convenient obstacle. | Feels contrived. Real conflicts are messier—they come from *within* the characters. | The real conflict is Liam’s fear of abandonment and Elen’s fear of being left behind. The paparazzi are just a catalyst. | | **Overly poetic or "impressive" prose** | The descriptions of the Welsh landscape are lush but *distanced*—like a travel brochure. The dialogue is littered with "clever" metaphors. | Feels pretentious. Real people don’t think in metaphors all the time. | The bookstore smells like dust and old tea. The rain sounds like static on a radio. Simple, sensory, *lived-in*. | | **The "bow" ending** | Liam and Elen ride off into the sunset (or stay in the bookstore forever) with no lingering doubts. The town throws them a party. | Feels unsatisfying. Real relationships have *uncertainty*, even in happy endings. | Liam stays, but he’s still figuring out how to balance his life. Elen is happy, but she’s also terrified. The ending is hopeful, not perfect. | | **Characters who are "too likable"** | Liam is charming but never *annoying*. Elen is sharp but never *cold*. They’re both *flawed in a way that’s easy to root for*. | Feels like a fantasy. Real people have *unlikeable* traits that we still love them for. | Liam can be *selfish* in a way that hurts Elen. Elen can be *judgmental* in a way that pushes Liam away. Their flaws *matter*. | | **Dialogue that’s "on brand" but not real** | Liam’s lines are *always* smooth and self-deprecating. Elen’s lines are *always* dry and sarcastic. They never *slip up*. | Feels like a performance. Real people *break character*—they say the wrong thing, they stumble over words. | Liam accidentally says something *too honest* and immediately regrets it. Elen *laughs at one of his jokes* and then *hates herself for it*. | | **A plot that serves the romance, not the characters** | Every event (the paparazzi, the storm, the tabloid scandal) *only* exists to push Liam and Elen together. | Feels like a machine. Real life has *unrelated* things happening—bills to pay, family drama, mundane problems. | Elen has to deal with a *broken pipe in the bookstore* while all this is happening. Liam gets a call from his *mother* who’s worried about him. | | **Avoiding discomfort** | The story *never* gets *too* dark or *too* messy. The conflict is *just* enough to be interesting, but not *too* real. | Feels sanitized. Real relationships have *pain*, *resentment*, and *uncertainty*. | Liam and Elen have a *real fight*—not just a misunderstanding, but a moment where they *hurt each other*. The make-up isn’t instant. | --- ### **Deep Dive: Critiquing the Intention & Plan for LLM Tropes** #### **1. The "Charming Rogue" Trope (and Why It’s Dangerous)** **Intention:** - Liam is a **charming but fragile actor** who uses his wit to mask his insecurities. His charm is a *shield*, and Elen is the first person who *sees through it*. **LLM Pitfall:** - **Risk of making him *too* charming.** If every line out of his mouth is a zinger, he becomes a *performance* rather than a person. - **Risk of making his vulnerability *too neat*.** If he "opens up" in a single heartfelt monologue, it feels *earned* but not *real*. - **Risk of making Elen’s resistance *too* perfect.** If she’s *completely* immune to his charm, she becomes a *plot device* rather than a person with her own flaws. **Human Alternative:** - **His charm should *fail* sometimes.** Maybe he tries to flirt with Elen, and she *doesn’t laugh*. Maybe he makes a joke, and it *falls flat*. - **His vulnerability should be *messy*.** Instead of a single "I’m scared" moment, it should come in *fits and starts*—he admits something, then *immediately* regrets it. - **Elen should *waver*.** She shouldn’t be *completely* immune—she should *almost* give in, then *catch herself*. **Brainstorm:** - **A moment where Liam *overplays his hand*.** He tries to impress Elen with a story, but she *calls him out* on it being a lie. He’s *shocked* that she saw through him. - **A moment where Elen *almost* laughs at his joke, then *stops herself*.** She *hates* that she *wanted* to laugh. - **A moment where Liam *accidentally* says something *too honest*.** He regrets it immediately, but Elen *files it away*. --- #### **2. The "Small Town vs. Big World" Trope (and Why It’s Cliché)** **Intention:** - The story contrasts **Elen’s rooted life in Wales** with **Liam’s transient Hollywood existence**. The town is *intimate and gossip-filled*, while Liam’s world is *glamorous and empty*. **LLM Pitfall:** - **Risk of making the small town *too quaint*.** If every local is *charming* and the town is *picture-perfect*, it feels like a *postcard* rather than a *real place*. - **Risk of making Liam’s world *too glamorous*.** If Hollywood is *all* red carpets and paparazzi, it feels *cartoonish* rather than *real*. - **Risk of making the conflict *too neat*.** If the *only* conflict is "city vs. country," it feels *reductive* rather than *nuanced*. **Human Alternative:** - **The small town should have *flaws*.** Maybe the locals are *nosy* in a way that’s *invasive*. Maybe the bookstore is *struggling financially*. Maybe the town has *its own scandals*. - **Liam’s world should have *depth*.** Maybe he’s *lonely* in Hollywood. Maybe he *misses his roots*. Maybe his fame is *more of a burden* than a blessing. - **The conflict should be *internal*.** The real conflict isn’t "city vs. country"—it’s **Liam’s fear of abandonment** and **Elen’s fear of being left behind**. **Brainstorm:** - **The town isn’t *all* charming.** The local gossip *hurts* Elen. The pub owner (Dafydd) is *skeptical* of Liam, not just *welcoming*. - **Liam’s fame is *isolating*.** He’s *surrounded by people* but *no one really knows him*. Maybe he *misses Wales* more than he lets on. - **The real conflict is *personal*.** Liam’s fear isn’t just about *leaving*—it’s about *being left*. Elen’s fear isn’t just about *staying*—it’s about *trusting*. --- #### **3. The "Fake Dating" Trope (and Why It’s Overdone)** **Intention:** - Liam and Elen *stage a relationship* to control the narrative, but the lines blur, and they *realize their feelings*. **LLM Pitfall:** - **Risk of making it *too predictable*.** If they *obviously* have feelings for each other, the fake dating feels *pointless*. - **Risk of making it *too neat*.** If they *decide to make it real* at the end, it feels *convenient* rather than *earned*. - **Risk of making the *scandal* feel *forced*.** If the tabloid story is *just* a plot device, it feels *contrived* rather than *real*. **Human Alternative:** - **The fake dating should *feel real*—but *not* in a way that’s *obvious*.** Maybe they *almost* kiss, but *stop themselves*. Maybe they *hold hands*, but it *feels awkward*. - **The scandal should *hurt* them.** Maybe Elen’s *reputation* is damaged. Maybe Liam’s *career* is at risk. - **The resolution should be *messy*.** Maybe they *don’t* make it real right away. Maybe they *fight* about it. **Brainstorm:** - **The fake dating *backfires*.** Maybe the town *believes it*, but Elen *hates* the attention. Maybe Liam *hates* lying to his fans. - **The scandal *has consequences*.** Maybe Elen’s bookstore *loses business*. Maybe Liam’s manager *drops him*. - **The resolution isn’t *instant*.** Maybe they *agree to try*, but it’s *not easy*. Maybe they *fight* about trust. --- #### **4. The "Neat Ending" Trope (and Why It’s Unrealistic)** **Intention:** - Liam *chooses Elen* over his career, and they *stay together* in the bookstore. **LLM Pitfall:** - **Risk of making it *too easy*.** If Liam *just* stays, it feels *unearned* rather than *real*. - **Risk of making it *too perfect*.** If everything *works out*, it feels *fantasy* rather than *life*. - **Risk of ignoring *real* obstacles.** If they *don’t* talk about *money, family, or logistics*, it feels *unrealistic*. **Human Alternative:** - **The ending should *acknowledge* the *difficulty*.** Maybe Liam *stays*, but he’s *still figuring out* how to balance his life. - **The ending should *leave some things open*.** Maybe Elen is *happy*, but she’s *still scared*. Maybe Liam is *committed*, but he’s *still learning*. - **The ending should *feel earned*.** Maybe they *fight* about trust. Maybe they *compromise* in a way that’s *not perfect*. **Brainstorm:** - **Liam *stays*, but it’s *not simple*.** Maybe he *keeps his apartment in L.A.* but *spends time in Wales*. Maybe he *takes smaller roles* to stay closer. - **Elen *trusts him*, but it’s *not instant*.** Maybe she *still worries* he’ll leave. Maybe she *needs reassurance*. - **The ending is *hopeful, not perfect*.** Maybe they’re *together*, but they’re *still figuring it out*. --- ### **5. The "Dialogue-Heavy" Trope (and Why It’s Not Realistic)** **Intention:** - The story is **dialogue-driven**, with **sharp banter** between Liam and Elen. **LLM Pitfall:** - **Risk of *too much talking*.** Real conversations have *pauses, silences, and non-verbal cues*. - **Risk of *too much wit*.** Real people *don’t* trade zingers all the time—they *stumble, repeat themselves, and say dumb things*. - **Risk of *no subtext*.** Real conversations *hide* as much as they *reveal*. **Human Alternative:** - **Include *silences and awkwardness*.** Maybe they *don’t know what to say*. Maybe one of them *changes the subject*. - **Let them *slip up*.** Maybe Liam *says the wrong thing*. Maybe Elen *laughs at a bad joke*. - **Use *subtext*.** Maybe they *say one thing* but *mean another*. Maybe they *avoid* talking about *what really matters*. **Brainstorm:** - **A moment where they *run out of things to say*.** They sit in *awkward silence*. One of them *fidgets*. - **A moment where Liam *accidentally insults Elen*.** He *immediately regrets it*, but the damage is done. - **A moment where Elen *avoids* talking about her *feelings*.** She *changes the subject* when Liam tries to ask. --- ### **6. The "Perfect Setting" Trope (and Why It’s Unrealistic)** **Intention:** - The **Welsh bookstore** is a **cozy, atmospheric** setting with **rain, old books, and tea**. **LLM Pitfall:** - **Risk of making it *too picturesque*.** If the bookstore is *always* *perfect*, it feels *like a movie set*. - **Risk of making it *too quiet*.** Real small towns have *noise, drama, and imperfections*. - **Risk of making it *too distant*.** If the setting is *just a backdrop*, it doesn’t *feel real*. **Human Alternative:** - **Include *flaws in the setting*.** Maybe the bookstore has a *leaky roof*. Maybe the town has *gossip and drama*. - **Make the setting *lived-in*.** Maybe the *tea is stale*. Maybe the *books are dusty*. - **Use the setting to *reflect the characters*.** Maybe the *bookstore is cluttered* because Elen *can’t let go of the past*. Maybe the *town is nosy* because it’s *protective*. **Brainstorm:** - **The bookstore has *problems*.** The *pipe is broken*. The *electricity is spotty*. - **The town has *drama*.** The *local pub owner* is *skeptical of Liam*. The *gossip* is *invasive*. - **The setting *reflects the characters*.** The *bookstore is Elen’s sanctuary*—but it’s also *her prison*. The *town is protective*—but also *suffocating*. --- ### **7. The "Emotional Arc" Trope (and Why It’s Too Neat)** **Intention:** - Liam and Elen have **clear, symmetrical character arcs**—Liam learns to be vulnerable, Elen learns to trust. **LLM Pitfall:** - **Risk of making the arcs *too neat*.** Real growth is *messy, inconsistent, and non-linear*. - **Risk of making the *conflict* too *clean*.** Real relationships have *resentment, fear, and uncertainty*. - **Risk of making the *resolution* too *easy*.** Real change takes *time, effort, and setbacks*. **Human Alternative:** - **Let the arcs *waver*.** Maybe Liam *reverts to his old habits*. Maybe Elen *doubts herself*. - **Include *real conflict*.** Maybe they *fight* about *trust*. Maybe they *hurt each other*. - **Make the resolution *earned*.** Maybe they *work at it*. Maybe they *don’t have all the answers*. **Brainstorm:** - **Liam *almost* reverts to his *old ways*.** He *flirts with someone else* out of habit, then *regrets it*. - **Elen *doubts herself*.** She *pushes Liam away* when she gets scared. - **They *fight* about *trust*.** Maybe Liam *does something* that *hurts Elen*. Maybe she *struggles to forgive him*. --- ### **Brainstorming: How to Make This More Human** #### **1. Embrace Imperfection in Dialogue** - **Include awkwardness.** Maybe Liam *trips over his words*. Maybe Elen *laughs at the wrong time*. - **Let them *slip up*.** Maybe Liam *says something* that *reveals too much*. Maybe Elen *accidentally insults him*. - **Use subtext.** Maybe they *say one thing* but *mean another*. Maybe they *avoid* talking about *what really matters*. **Example:** - **Liam:** *"You know, most people would be flattered if a famous actor hid in their bookstore."* - **Elen:** *"Most people don’t have a business to run."* - *(Silence. Liam fidgets with his cufflink.)* - **Liam:** *"Right. Of course. Sorry."* #### **2. Make the Conflict Internal (Not Just External)** - **Liam’s fear isn’t just about *leaving*—it’s about *being left*.** Maybe his parents *abandoned him* as a kid. Maybe he’s *terrified* of being *unlovable*. - **Elen’s fear isn’t just about *staying*—it’s about *trusting*.** Maybe her ex *cheated on her*. Maybe she’s *afraid* of *getting hurt again*. - **The real conflict is *within them*.** The paparazzi, the town, the scandal—these are *catalysts*, not the *real* problem. **Example:** - **Elen:** *"You’ll leave. They always do."* - **Liam:** *"Who’s *they*?"* - **Elen:** *"Does it matter?"* - *(Liam looks at her. Really looks at her.)* - **Liam:** *"Yeah. It does."* #### **3. Let the Setting Be Flawed (Not Perfect)** - **The bookstore isn’t *magical*—it’s *real*.** Maybe the *tea is stale*. Maybe the *books are dusty*. - **The town isn’t *charming*—it’s *complicated*.** Maybe the *locals are nosy*. Maybe the *gossip is hurtful*. - **The landscape isn’t *postcard-perfect*—it’s *lived-in*.** Maybe the *rain is cold*. Maybe the *sheep are annoying*. **Example:** - The bookstore’s *pipe bursts* while Liam is hiding there. Elen is *furious*—not just at the mess, but at the *inconvenience*. - The *town throws a party* for Liam, but it *feels forced*. The locals are *polite*, but they’re *watching him*. #### **4. Make the Romance *Messy* (Not Just *Cute*)** - **They *fight*.** Maybe Liam *does something* that *hurts Elen*. Maybe she *pushes him away* when she’s scared. - **They *doubt*.** Maybe Liam *wonders if he’s good enough*. Maybe Elen *wonders if she can trust him*. - **They *grow*—but not *in a straight line*.** Maybe Liam *reverts to his old habits*. Maybe Elen *doubts herself*. **Example:** - **Liam:** *"I can’t do this. I’m not—I’m not the guy you think I am."* - **Elen:** *"Then who *are* you?"* - *(Liam doesn’t answer. He just *walks away*.)* #### **5. Avoid the "Bow" Ending** - **Don’t make it *too neat*.** Maybe Liam *stays*, but he’s *still figuring it out*. - **Don’t make it *too perfect*.** Maybe Elen is *happy*, but she’s *still scared*. - **Leave *some things open*.** Maybe they’re *together*, but they’re *still working on it*. **Example:** - **Liam:** *"I’m not going back. Not for good."* - **Elen:** *"What does that mean?"* - **Liam:** *"It means I’m here. For now. And we’ll figure out the rest."* - *(Elen looks at him. She *wants to believe him*. But she’s *still scared*.)* --- ### **Final Thoughts: How to Make This Story Feel Human** 1. **Write the *awkward* moments.** The silences, the stumbles, the times when they *say the wrong thing*. 2. **Make the *conflict internal*.** The real problem isn’t the paparazzi—it’s *what’s inside them*. 3. **Let the *setting be flawed*.** The bookstore isn’t *perfect*—it’s *real*. The town isn’t *charming*—it’s *complicated*. 4. **Embrace *messy growth*.** They don’t *magically* change—they *struggle*, they *backslide*, they *keep trying*. 5. **Avoid the *bow*.** The ending should *feel real*—not *perfect*. --- **Next Steps:** - **Re-examine the chapter plan** with these humanizing principles in mind. - **Brainstorm *specific* scenes where the characters *fail, stumble, or doubt*. - **Decide how to *weave in* the *flaws* of the setting (the leaky pipe, the nosy locals, the stale tea).** Would you like to dive deeper into any of these areas (e.g., specific scenes, dialogue examples, or setting details)?
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
--- ### **# Intention** #### **Core Intentions (Synthesized from Brainstorming & Humanizing Critique)** This short story will be a **raw, emotionally honest romance** set in a **small Welsh town**, centered on the **clash and reluctant connection** between a **charming but fragile Hollywood actor** and a **sharp-witted, guarded bookstore owner**. The tone will balance **dry humor, tension, and vulnerability**, with a **strong emphasis on authentic dialogue, flawed characters, and a setting that feels lived-in**. --- #### **Key Choices & Intentions** **1. Plot & Structure: Serving the Characters, Not the Romance** - **Avoid:** A **predictable, formulaic rom-com** where every conflict exists *only* to push Liam and Elen together. - **Embrace:** - **Forced proximity as a catalyst, not a gimmick.** Liam hiding in the bookstore should feel **organic to their personalities**—Elen is **practical but not heartless**, Liam is **desperate but not manipulative**. - **External conflict as a mirror for internal struggles.** The paparazzi, the town’s gossip, the tabloid scandal—these should **force Liam and Elen to confront their fears**, not just provide obstacles to overcome. - **A slow burn with *real* stakes.** The first half should focus on **tension, banter, and simmering attraction**, while the second half should **delve into vulnerability, doubt, and messy growth**. **2. Character Arcs: Flawed, Human, and Earned** - **Liam Calloway:** - **Starts as:** A **charming, performative rogue** who uses wit to mask his insecurities. His charm is a **shield**, but it’s **fragile**. - **Growth:** He **learns to be vulnerable**, but not in a **neat, three-act journey**. His progress should be **messy, inconsistent, and hard-won**. - **Key Moment:** He **turns down a major role** to stay with Elen—but it’s **not a grand gesture**. It’s a **quiet, uncertain choice**, and he’s **still figuring out what it means**. - **Avoid:** Making him *too* likable. He should **annoy Elen sometimes**. He should **say the wrong thing**. He should **struggle with his own flaws**. - **Elen Morgan:** - **Starts as:** A **cynical, guarded bookstore owner** who resists Liam’s charm out of **self-preservation**. She’s **sharp, but not unkind**. - **Growth:** She **learns to trust**, but not **instantly or easily**. She should **doubt herself**, **push Liam away**, and **struggle with her own fears**. - **Key Moment:** She **calls Liam out on his bullshit**—not just once, but **multiple times**. Her **trust is earned, not given**. - **Avoid:** Making her *too* resistant. She should **waver**. She should **almost give in**, then **catch herself**. **3. Voice & Dialogue: Authentic, Not Performative** - **Avoid:** **Overly witty, zinger-filled dialogue** that feels **forced or unrealistic**. - **Embrace:** - **Real conversations have pauses, awkwardness, and subtext.** Liam and Elen should **stumble over their words**. They should **say the wrong thing**. They should **avoid talking about what really matters**. - **Their voices should reflect their personalities:** - **Liam:** Smooth, teasing, but **with moments of vulnerability**. His **accent slips** when he’s **nervous or honest**. - **Elen:** Dry, sarcastic, but **with moments of softness**. Her **Welsh lilt is more pronounced** when she’s **emotional or tired**. - **Subtext is key.** They should **say one thing but mean another**. They should **hide their feelings behind humor or anger**. **4. Setting: Lived-In, Not Picturesque** - **Avoid:** Making the **Welsh bookstore or town feel like a postcard**—**too charming, too quiet, too perfect**. - **Embrace:** - **The bookstore is *real*.** It’s **cluttered, slightly run-down, and smells like old paper and stale tea**. The **pipe leaks**. The **electricity flickers**. - **The town is *complicated*.** The **locals are nosy**, but not **all kind**. The **gossip is invasive**, but not **without reason**. - **The landscape is *raw*.** The **rain is cold**. The **wind howls**. The **sheep are annoying**. - **The setting should reflect the characters.** The **bookstore is Elen’s sanctuary—but also her prison**. The **town is protective—but also suffocating**. **5. Themes: Authenticity, Fear, and Messy Growth** - **Authenticity vs. Performance:** Liam’s **entire life is an act**, but Elen **sees through it**—and makes him want to be **real**. - **Fear of Abandonment vs. Fear of Trust:** Liam is **terrified of being left**, Elen is **terrified of trusting**. - **Small Town vs. Big World:** The **clash between Elen’s rooted life and Liam’s transient existence**—but the **real conflict is internal**. - **The Illusion of Fame:** Liam’s **charm is a shield**, and Elen’s **indifference is the first thing that *actually* reaches him**. **6. Tone & Pacing: Tense, Vulnerable, and Unflinching** - **First Half (Chapters 1-4):** **Witty, tense, slow-burn romance**—focus on **banter, forced proximity, and simmering attraction**. - **Pacing:** **Steady but deliberate**. Let the **tension build** before the payoff. - **Avoid:** Making it **too cute or too light**. There should be **moments of discomfort, doubt, and awkwardness**. - **Second Half (Chapters 5-8):** **More emotional, higher stakes**—focus on **vulnerability, conflict, and messy resolution**. - **Pacing:** **Faster, but not rushed**. The **conflict should feel urgent**, but the **resolution should feel earned**. - **Avoid:** A **neat, bow-wrapped ending**. The **resolution should feel real—not perfect**. **7. Stylistic Choices: Sensory, Subtextual, and Unflinching** - **Sensory Details:** Use **smell, sound, and texture** to **immerse the reader**. - The **bookstore smells like dust and old tea**. The **rain sounds like static on a radio**. The **wind howls through the cracks in the windows**. - **Subtext Over Explanation:** **Show, don’t tell**. Let the **reader infer emotions** from **actions and dialogue**. - Instead of *"Liam’s heart raced with longing,"* show him **fidgeting with his cufflinks**. - Instead of *"Elen’s walls crumbled,"* show her **avoiding eye contact**. - **Unflinching Honesty:** **Don’t soften the messy parts**. If Liam **says the wrong thing**, show the **consequences**. If Elen **pushes him away**, show the **pain**. --- ### **# Chapter Planning** #### **Chapter 1: The Hideout (Meet-Cute/Gone Wrong) – 1000 words** - **Key Events:** - Liam **bursts into the bookstore**, breathless, asking Elen to hide him from the paparazzi. - She’s **skeptical but relents**, leading him to the **back room**. - Their **first conversation is a battle of wits**—he tries to charm her; she shuts it down. - **Key Moment:** He notices a book she’s reading (*Wuthering Heights*) and teases her. She snaps back, but he *sees* her—for the first time. - **Ending:** The paparazzi pass by the window. Liam tenses. Elen, without thinking, pulls him into the back room. Their hands brush. A beat of silence. - **Humanizing Choices:** - **Liam’s charm *fails*.** He tries to flirt, but she **doesn’t laugh**. - **Elen is *not* impressed.** She **calls him out** on his bullshit. - **The setting is *real*.** The bookstore is **cluttered, slightly run-down**. The **tea is stale**. - **Subtext is key.** They **say one thing but mean another**. #### **Chapter 2: The Truce (Forced Proximity) – 1000 words** - **Key Events:** - Liam is **stuck in the bookstore for the night** (paparazzi are camped outside). - Elen is **furious at the disruption** but also… intrigued. - They **bicker over tea and biscuits**. He tries to impress her with Hollywood stories; she calls him out on his bullshit. - **Key Moment:** He admits he’s **terrified of being exposed as a fraud**. She softens—just a little. - **Ending:** She lends him a book (*The Great Gatsby*). He reads a passage aloud to her. She pretends not to be affected. - **Humanizing Choices:** - **The tea is *stale*.** The **biscuits are dry**. - **Liam *slips up*.** He **says something too honest**, then **immediately regrets it**. - **Elen *wavers*.** She **almost laughs at his joke**, then **catches herself**. - **The setting is *lived-in*.** The **pipe leaks**. The **electricity flickers**. #### **Chapter 3: The Town Finds Out (Chaos Ensues) – 1000 words** - **Key Events:** - **Seren walks in and loses her mind** when she sees Liam. The secret is out. - The **town is abuzz**. The paparazzi swarm. - Elen is **mortified**. Liam is… oddly protective of her. - **Key Moment:** A photographer shoves a camera in Elen’s face. Liam steps between them, snarling. She’s shocked—no one’s ever defended her like that. - **Ending:** The local constable kicks the paparazzi out of town—for now. Liam is "invited" to stay at the pub (Dafydd’s place) to lay low. - **Humanizing Choices:** - **The town’s reaction is *mixed*.** Some love him; some resent the disruption. - **Dafydd is *skeptical*.** He **doesn’t trust Liam** and **says so**. - **Elen is *flustered*.** She **doesn’t know how to feel** about Liam’s protectiveness. - **The setting is *invasive*.** The **paparazzi are everywhere**. The **town is gossipy**. #### **Chapter 4: The Pub (Public Scrutiny) – 1000 words** - **Key Events:** - Liam is now **everyone’s problem**. The town is divided—some love him, some resent the disruption. - Elen **avoids him**, but he seeks her out. They argue in the pub’s garden. - **Key Moment:** He asks why she’s so determined to hate him. She snaps: *"Because people like you don’t stay. And I’m not some holiday fling for a celebrity."* - **Ending:** A **storm rolls in**. They’re forced to take shelter in the pub’s cellar. Tension simmers. - **Humanizing Choices:** - **The pub is *loud and crowded*.** The **locals are nosy**. - **Liam is *frustrated*.** He **doesn’t know how to prove himself**. - **Elen is *defensive*.** She **pushes him away** when he gets too close. - **The storm is *unpredictable*.** The **cellar is dark and damp**. #### **Chapter 5: The Confession (Vulnerability) – 1000 words** - **Key Events:** - **Trapped in the cellar**, they talk—*really* talk. - Liam admits he’s **lonely**. Elen admits she’s **afraid of being left behind**. - **Key Moment:** He kisses her. She kisses back—then pushes him away. *"This is a bad idea."* - **Ending:** The storm passes. They emerge to find the town has **thrown a party** in Liam’s honor. He’s horrified. She’s amused. - **Humanizing Choices:** - **The kiss is *awkward*.** They **both pull away**, unsure. - **Liam is *vulnerable*.** He **admits his fears**, but it’s **not neat or pretty**. - **Elen is *conflicted*.** She **wants to trust him**, but she’s **still scared**. - **The party is *forced*.** The **locals are polite**, but it **feels fake**. #### **Chapter 6: The Scandal (External Conflict) – 1000 words** - **Key Events:** - A **tabloid runs a story**: *"LIAM CALLOWAY’S SECRET WELSH LOVER!"* (Complete with a blurry photo of them in the bookstore.) - Elen is **humiliated**. Liam is *furious*—not at the exposure, but at the invasion of *her* privacy. - **Key Moment:** He offers to leave town to protect her. She refuses. *"I’m not hiding. And neither are you."* - **Ending:** They devise a plan—to give the paparazzi *exactly* what they want… but on their terms. - **Humanizing Choices:** - **The scandal *hurts*.** Elen’s **reputation is damaged**. Liam’s **career is at risk**. - **Liam is *protective*.** He **doesn’t want to leave her**, but he’s **willing to** if it’s what she wants. - **Elen is *defiant*.** She **refuses to hide**, but she’s **still scared**. - **The plan is *messy*.** It’s **not a neat solution**—it’s a **risky, uncertain choice**. #### **Chapter 7: The Performance (Fake Dating?) – 1000 words** - **Key Events:** - They **stage a "romantic" walk through town**, feeding the paparazzi a story. - But the lines blur. The kisses feel real. The town starts shipping them. - **Key Moment:** Liam’s manager calls, offering him a **huge role**—if he dumps Elen for a "more marketable" girlfriend. - **Ending:** Liam hesitates. Elen overhears. She’s gutted. - **Humanizing Choices:** - **The fake dating *backfires*.** The **town believes it**, but Elen **hates the attention**. - **Liam is *torn*.** He **doesn’t want to lose Elen**, but he’s **tempted by the role**. - **Elen is *hurt*.** She **feels like a pawn**, and she’s **furious**. - **The moment is *messy*.** It’s **not a clean break**—it’s a **painful, uncertain choice**. #### **Chapter 8: The Choice (Resolution) – 1000 words** - **Key Events:** - Liam shows up at the bookstore, ready to grovel. Elen is **ice-cold**. - He admits he **turned down the role**. *"I’d rather be here. With you."* - **Key Moment:** She calls his bluff—*"Prove it. Stay. Not for a week. Not for a scandal. Stay."* - **Ending:** He does. The paparazzi leave. The town accepts him. And in the quiet of the bookstore, with rain on the windows, he reads to her from *North and South*—and this time, she doesn’t pretend not to listen. - **Humanizing Choices:** - **The ending is *not perfect*.** Liam **stays**, but he’s **still figuring it out**. - **Elen is *still scared*.** She **wants to trust him**, but she’s **still unsure**. - **The resolution is *earned*.** They **don’t have all the answers**, but they’re **willing to try**. - **The setting is *real*.** The **bookstore is still cluttered**. The **rain is still cold**. --- **Final Notes:** - **Each chapter should feel *human*—not polished, not perfect, but *real*.** - **The dialogue should *stumble, slip, and reveal*—not just *sparkle*.** - **The setting should *feel lived-in*—not like a postcard, but like a *home*.** - **The resolution should *feel earned*—not neat, not easy, but *real*.** Would you like to dive deeper into any specific chapter or scene?
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
--- ### **# Liam Calloway** #### **Background** - **Full Name:** Liam Rhys Calloway - **Age:** 32 - **Hometown:** **Swansea, Wales** (though he’s spent the last decade in L.A., he still has a faint Welsh accent that slips out when he’s tired or emotional). - **Family:** - **Mother (Megan):** A former nurse who worked long shifts at the local hospital. She was **warm but distant**—always exhausted, always putting others first. She died of cancer when Liam was 18, leaving him with a **deep-seated fear of abandonment**. - **Father (Dylan):** A **charming but unreliable** salesman who left when Liam was 10. He’d show up every few years with **big promises and empty pockets**, then disappear again. Liam **hates him** but also **craves his approval**. - **No siblings**—just him and his mum, then just him. - **Early Life:** - Grew up in a **small, terraced house** in Swansea, where the **walls were thin and the heating was unreliable**. - **School:** He was **bright but restless**, always acting in school plays, always the **class clown**. Teachers called him *"talented but undisciplined."* - **First Job:** Worked at a **local cinema**, selling tickets and sneaking into films. That’s where he **fell in love with acting**—not just performing, but **becoming someone else**. - **Break into Acting:** - Moved to **London at 19** with **£200 and a dream**. Slept on couches, waited tables, auditioned for **every small role he could find**. - **First Big Break:** A **gritty indie film** where he played a **small-time criminal**. His **raw, unpolished performance** caught the attention of a **Hollywood agent**. - **Hollywood:** Moved to L.A. at **24**, where he **reinvented himself**—**smoother, more charming, less "Welsh."** He **buried his accent, his past, his fears** under a **layer of polish**. - **Now:** A **rising star**—not *A-list*, but **recognizable, sought-after, and slightly infamous** for his **roguish charm and on-set feuds**. #### **Personality** - **Core Traits:** - **Charming but fragile**—his **wit is a shield**, but it’s **not impenetrable**. - **Self-deprecating but secretly vain**—he **jokes about his flaws**, but he **hates being ignored**. - **Lonely but afraid of intimacy**—he **craves connection**, but he **pushes people away** before they can leave him. - **Flaws:** - **Needs validation**—if someone doesn’t like him, he **overcompensates** with jokes or charm. - **Avoids vulnerability**—if he **feels too much**, he **makes a joke or walks away**. - **Self-sabotaging**—if things get **too real**, he **does something to ruin it**. - **Idiosyncrasies (Trivial but Grounding):** - **Always fidgets with his cufflinks** when he’s nervous. - **Hates silence**—if there’s a pause in conversation, he **fills it with a joke or a story**. - **Secretly loves bad reality TV**—he **watches it in hotel rooms** when he’s lonely. - **Has a habit of stealing spoons** from restaurants (a **childhood nervous tic** he never grew out of). - **Hates the smell of hospitals** (triggers memories of his mum). - **Always carries a **small, worn copy of *The Great Gatsby*** in his bag (a **gift from his mum**). #### **Physicality** - **Appearance:** - **Height:** 5’11” (tall enough to feel imposing, but not *too* tall). - **Build:** Lean but **not skinny**—he **works out, but not obsessively**. - **Hair:** **Dark brown, slightly too long**, always **slightly messy** (like he’s just rolled out of bed or a photoshoot). - **Eyes:** **Hazel-green**, **sharp and observant**—they **miss nothing**. - **Skin:** **Pale with a hint of stubble** (he **shaves every morning**, but by afternoon, he’s **rough around the edges**). - **Style:** **Effortlessly cool**—**dark jeans, a well-fitted sweater, a **leather jacket** he’s had since he was 20. He **dresses like he doesn’t care**, but he **cares too much**. - **How He Carries Himself:** - **Confident but not arrogant**—he **owns a room**, but he’s **not a jerk about it**. - **Expressive with his hands**—he **gestures when he talks**, **touches people’s arms** when he’s being charming. - **Avoids eye contact when he’s lying** (a **tell** he’s **tried to hide**). - **How He Interacts with the World:** - **People are drawn to him**—he’s **funny, warm, and **easy to talk to**. - **But he’s also **exhausting**—he **demands attention**, and if he doesn’t get it, he **acts out**. - **He notices small details**—the **way someone holds their tea**, the **way they laugh**, the **way they avoid his eyes**. #### **Motives, Allegiances, Relationships** - **Motives:** - **To be loved**—but **not to need it**. - **To prove he’s not his father**—that he **won’t leave, that he’s reliable**. - **To escape his past**—but **also to be seen for it**. - **Allegiances:** - **His agent (Claire):** A **shark in a pantsuit** who **pushed him to reinvent himself**. He **respects her**, but he **resents her** for **erasing parts of him**. - **His co-stars:** He **likes them**, but he **doesn’t let them get too close**. - **The paparazzi:** He **hates them**, but he **needs them** (they **validate his existence**). - **Existing Relationships:** - **His best friend (Jake):** A **comedy writer** he met in L.A. The **only person who really knows him**—but even Jake **doesn’t know the worst of it**. - **His ex (Sophie):** A **model** who **left him for a director**. He **still checks her Instagram**. - **The town of Llanfair:** He **doesn’t know them**, but he **wants them to like him**—**desperately**. #### **Voice & Dialogue (Flavour Examples)** - **Charming but performative:** - *"You know, most people would be flattered if a famous actor hid in their bookstore. But you? You look like I just tracked mud on your carpet."* - *"I’m not *that* bad, am I? Oh god, I am. I’m *terrible*.
